bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, WESTERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of Wah Ni for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
State of Washington, County of Pierce
Moy Yuck being first duly sworn on his oath deposes and says:

That he has resided in Portland, Oregon, for over thirty years last past, and is engaged in business in said city at 246 Yamhill St., as member of the firm of Hop Wah Lung; that he is well and personally acquainted with Wah Ni and knows that the said Wah Ni is a member of the firm of Yee Wah & Co., dealers in Chinese and Japanese merchandise at 254 Morrison Street in Portland, and that he has been a member of said firm between three and four years; and deponent further says that he is the Moy Yuck who made application on behalf of said Wah Ni for a Writ of Habeas Corpus in the Superior Court of the State of Washington, for the County of Pierce, and that he made the same for the reason that the said Wah Ni was not informed by the Collector of Customs or the depu- ty in charge, that he would not be allowed to land until the night of the 8th day of May, at about the hour of Five o ' clock, when he was informed by said Collector of Customs or some other person in charge that he would not be allowed to come ashore, but would be forced to remain on said vessel Victoria and return to China and that said vessel intended to leave on the morning of the 9th of May at 4 o'clock; and deponent further says that the members of said firm of which Wah Ni is a member are Moy Ham, Ne Yong and Charlie Hing, and are doing buisiness at 254 Morrison Street and have been for abou four years last past; and deponent further says that to his own personal knowlege, the said Wah Ni, is a good, respectable and bona fide Chinese merchant of the United States

and has been for between and three and four years, deponent stat- ing upon oath that he knows him that time as a merchant and knew him at lease six years prior to that time and that he still has and re- tains his interest in said firm and deponent frequently conversed with him and the members of his saidbfirm, being intimately ac- quanited with each of them and says that he is a joint owner in said firm and as deponent is informed and verily believes has an interest to the extent of $1000, and that he is still engaged in- terested in said business and deponent says that the said Wah Ni is a good, honest, upright and bona fide Chinese merchant of the United States.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 7th day of June, 1893
Notary Public in and for Pierce County, Residing at Tacoma, Washington.
